title: Former PSG full back Alves reveals there are 'a lot of f****ing racists' in Paris
text:
Dani Alves has spoken out about his 'tiresome' spell at Paris Saint-Germain and says the French capital is inhabited by 'a lot of f****** racists'.

The Brazilian right back, now plying his trade at home in Sao Paulo, spent two years in Paris after leaving Juventus and, before that, Barcelona.

Speaking in an interview with GQ, he said of his time at PSG: 'Paris is a stressful city, I don't like it much. If you go to Paris for a week, it will be the adventure of your lifetime. More than that, it is tiresome.

Dani Alves (bottom) spent two seasons at PSG and won the Ligue 1 title on both occasions

Alves, pictured out and about in Paris during time at PSG, says city has 'a lot of f***ing racists'

'It reminds a bit of Sao Paulo. But there, they are f***ing racists. A lot of them. To me, they didn't do anything, because I would have told them to go f*** themselves, but I saw it with my friends.'

Alves has had to deal with racism on numerous occasions in the past, most famously when he had a banana thrown at him while playing for Barcelona in 2014.

During the clash against Villarreal, the incident occurred as Alves prepared to take a corner - and the full back picked up the fruit and took a bite before carrying on with the match.

He was praised by fellow professionals and fans alike, and thousands posted pictures of themselves with bananas in solidarity with the Barcelona man.

Taking to Twitter at the time, Gary Lineker wrote: 'Picked it up, peeled it, ate it and proceeded to take the corner. Top response.'

Alves is now back in Brazil and plying his trade for Sao Paulo at the grand old age of 36

Back in 2014, Alves had a banana thrown at him - and he decided to pick it up and take a bite

The ex-England striker added: 'Utterly brilliant reaction from Alves. Treat the racist berk with complete disdain!'

Alves left Barcelona in 2016, spending a year at Juventus before heading to Paris Saint-Germain.

While in France, he won two league titles in two seasons, before heading back to his home country this summer at the age of 36.

Racism has once again been top of the news agenda this week after England's black players were abused by Bulgaria fans making monkey noises and doing Nazi salutes.

The Three Lions' qualifying match in Sofia was halted twice by the referee, and in the aftermath of the racist abuse the Bulgarian FA president resigned from his position.

The linesman watches as Alves takes a bite from a banana that was thrown onto the pitch
description: The Brazilian right back, now plying his trade at home in Sao Paulo, spent two years in Paris after leaving Juventus and, before that, Barcelona. But he didn't much enjoy his time in the French capital.
